_prev_prog_2.Description: The Cedar Piney Water Treatment Plant is a municipal facility owned by the City of Danville.  This facility falls under the NAICS Code 22131.  The last review and/or update of the safety information was on October 13, 2000.  We are subject to the handling codes of the National Fire Protection Association for compressed gas cylinder storage, American National Standards Institute, and American Society of Mechanical Engineers.  These standards, along with applicable (though not required) OSHA Standards have been implemented through written manuals.  Even though this is a municipal facility, and is not governed by OSHA, Cedar Piney Water Treatment Plant has decided to use portions of OSHA's Process Safety Management as the prevention program (level 3).  To prevent/limit releases, this facility operates the chlorine feed system on an automatic vacuum feed system, manual shutoff valves, and delayed manual fan operation to control/limit the release.  The vacuum feed regulators are cylinder mounted, therefore, the system will shut off the chlorine feed from the cylinders if there is a feed line leak anywhere from the chlorine tank valve to the ejector.  Employees at the water treatment plant conduct maintenance checks on all systems involved with the chlorine on a daily basis.  These checks involve checking chlorine cylinder weights, inspecting cylinders, feed lines, etc.  Also, the cylinder hoist is inspected on a montly basis to ensure safe operations when cylinders are changed out.  Employees at the water treatment plant practice safe handling  of chlorine, and follow manuafacturer's recommendation on Wallace & Tiernan chlorine system operational & maniantenance procedures.  All employees are trained in the maintenance and operating procedures at this facility when they are hires, and throughout their employment.  The operating and training procedures were last reviewed and/or updated on October 14, 1999.  The employees at the Cedar Piney Water Plant are trained by on-the-job training, and are tested by observation and demonstration.  The last review of maintenance procedures was October 14, 1999.  There have been no accidents or releases in the past five years.  The last hazard review was conducted ion October 14, 1999 by use of a fault tree analysis.  The resulsts of the hazard analysis were the need for a btter visual alarm which can be seen from a greater distance,.  Also the need for outside perimter monitoring to indicate a release of chlorine  when the plant is not manned (nightime).  This can be accomplished by installing a phone relay line from the chlorine alarm to the Plant Manager's house, as well as two other phone numbers.  Both hazard findings should be completed by December 31, 2001.  This Prevention Program for this facility is required to be a Level 2, however, portions of a Level 3 PSM Prevention Program has been added for implementation to allow for a more effective release prevention program.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
In this water treatment plant facility (Cedar Piney Water Treatment Plant) we handle chlorine which is considered hazardous by EPA, OSHA, etc.  The same properties that makes chlorine valuable as a water treatment chemical, also makes it necessary to observe certain precautions in handling chlorine.  Overall, the prevention of unnecessary human exposures, reducing the threat to our own personnal health as well as our co-workers, and reducing the threat to nearby members of the communtiy is the main goal of incorporating this Risk Management Plan into our daily operations.  It is our policy to adhere to all applicable federal and state rules and regulations.  Safety depends upon the manner in which we handle and use chlorine, combined with the safety devices inherent in the design of this facility, with the safe handling proceduresthat we utilize, along with the training of our personnel.

The primary purpose of this facility is to treat the water supply by utilizing chemicals such as chlorine.  Chlorine is received by individual one ton cylinders and stored until needed.  Chlorine is fed into the water system by automatic vacuum operated feeders.  The vacuum system will help prevent the continual operation of the chlorine feed from the cylinder if there is an increase or decrease in pressure on the feed lines (if a feed line is cut or split).  Access to the site is restricted to authorized facility employees, authorized management personnel, and authorized contractors.  The maximum amount of chlorine at this the Cedar Piney Water Treatment Plant is 6,000 pounds.

Our employees conduct proper cylinder change-out procedures when cylinders are changed out.  These procedures are based on the Manufacturer's recommendations.  Employees also review operating procedures and maintenance tasks daily or as need per manufacturer's recommendations.  The prevention program for this facility is a Level 2.  Lockout/Tagout procedures are used to help prevent an accidental release of

chlorine.  When maintenance is conducted on the chlorination system, the Water Superintendent (Jeyy Pendergraft) approves the proper installation of materials, and complete installation.  Any change in maintenance procedures is reviewed and approved by the same manager.  All operators at this facility are knowledgeable in the proper start-up and shut-down procedures for the water treatment operations.  All components of the chlorination system are visually inspected at least once every day.

Our emergency response (action) plan was developed with the assistance of Environmental Data Services, Inc.,  the Danville Fire Department, and the Yell County Office of Emergency Services.  If a chlorine release occurs at the Highway 10 West & CR574 location, the chlorine alarm will sound to notify plant personnel of a release.  Water Superintendent (Jerry Pendergraft) will get personel organized for an emergency action, and if necessary, response and evacuation.  Fire Fighting personnel have SCBA equipment that they will use to enter the confined space (due to toxic atmosphere) and determine extent of release.  They can perform an emergency action by manual shutdown of the chlorine cylinder valve.  If the release cannot be controlled by the manual valve shutdown, then evacuation procedures will then be followed.  A head count will be made of employees and A.D. Morris (City Manager) will be notified, then the 911 call will be made to notify the Danville Fire Department (HazMat Responders), Yell County Office of Emergency Services, and the Yell County Sheriff's Office of the release.  Personnel at the  Highway 10 West & CR574 location, the Danville Fire Department, and Yell County Office of Emergency Services will help organize the Emergency Response activities, and will start the evacuation of the affected population.  The release could be slowed by employees not starting the manual vent system in the chlorine room until notification to 911 system is made, and evacuation activ

ities begin.  This will not prevent chlorine from releasing, but will allow for some time to respond.

The worst case scenario for this facility is a one ton cylinder failure, which would be a release of 2,000 pounds of chlorine gas into the atmosphere.  Active mitigation has been considered for this scenario consisting of manual shutoffs, and automatic vacuum feed chlorine system.  Passive mitigation has also been considered for this release scenario, which would be a release into an enclosed space with little contact with outsisde air.  It is assumed that the entire contents of the cylinder are released as vapor.  The distance to endpoint of 0.087 mg/l for the worst case scenario is 2.2 miles.  The area surrounding the facility is considered to be rural due to thenon vegetative and flat terrain.  The worst case scenario would impact approximately 2,100 persons.

An alternate release scenario was determined for the  Highway 10 West & CR574 location.  The chlorine cylinders operate on an automatic vacuum fedd system, so the amount of chlorine released at these locations would be minimal (approximately 10 pounds).  This release of chlorine would impact approximately 50 persons.  All populations were based on Landview Software.

There have been no accidents or accidental releases of chlorine from this facility in the past five years.  The automatic vacuum feed system helps prevent/limit releases of chlorine that could escape during operational periods.  Operators of the chlorination system are required to check instruments, cylinders, feed lines, etc. on a daily basis to aid in the prevention of accidental releases.  Even though this is a Level 2 Prevention Program, Danville Water Works has chosen to utilize portions of a Level 3 Process Safety Management Program to furthur emphasize their efforts in preventing accidental releases of chlorine.
